dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, there's been some interesting news coming out of the U.K. this week, particularly regarding data and political campaigns. The Information Commissioner's Office, the ICO, they've been looking into pro-Brexit campaigns' use of data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, there's been some interesting news coming out of the U K this week, particularly regarding data and political campaigns. The Information Commissioner's Office, the I C O, they've been looking into pro Brexit campaigns' use of data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The news comes as the U.K. Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) released a report into pro-Brexit campaigns' use of data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, I saw that. And it's resulted in some proposed fines, right? For like, Aaron Banks and Leave.EU, totaling, uh, £135,000.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, I saw that. And it's resulted in some proposed fines, right? For like, Aaron Banks and Leave dot E U, totaling, uh, one hundred thirty five thousand pounds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That resulted in proposed fines on organizations run by Brexit's biggest single donor, Aaron Banks, and Leave.EU totalling £135,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But what's really catching my eye is that the ICO's Brexit probe, it actually didn't expand to *all* tracking practices at Facebook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But what's really catching my eye is that the I C O's Brexit probe, it actually didn't expand to all tracking practices at Facebook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokesperson for ICO said its Brexit probe didn't expand to some tracking practises at Facebook.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right! And so, they've just, like, handed that information over to Ireland's Data Protection Commission, the DPC. Which, if I remember correctly, is Facebook's lead supervisory authority under GDPR.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! And so, they've just, like, handed that information over to Ireland's Data Protection Commission, the D P C. Which, if I remember correctly, is Facebook's lead supervisory authority under G D P R.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And so it's handed the information it obtained during the investigation to Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC). As per the ICO's report released Tuesday morning: We are in the process of referring other outstanding issues about Facebooks targeting functions and techniques used to monitor individuals' browsing habits, interactions and behaviour across the internet and different devices to the Irish Data Protection Commission, as the lead supervisory authority for Facebook under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty wild. They're referring "outstanding issues" about Facebook's targeting functions, uh, the techniques used to monitor individuals' browsing habits, interactions across the internet, different devices... all of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty wild. They're referring outstanding issues about Facebook's targeting functions, uh, the techniques used to monitor individuals' browsing habits, interactions across the internet, different devices... all of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are in the process of referring other outstanding issues about Facebooks targeting functions and techniques used to monitor individuals' browsing habits, interactions and behaviour across the internet and different devices to the Irish Data Protection Commission, as the lead supervisory authority for Facebook under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And, um, fake ads too, I heard? That's part of the referral?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, um, fake ads too, I heard? That's part of the referral?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The ICO spokesperson told Forbes fake ads would be included in that referral.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's been an embarrassing month for Facebook, hasn't it? Like, think about The Intercept finding they could advertise to people interested in "white genocide."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's been an embarrassing month for Facebook, hasn't it? Like, think about The Intercept finding they could advertise to people interested in white genocide.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Intercept found last week it could advertise to those interested in white genocide.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, God, yeah. And that was, like, right after the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting. Just awful timing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, God, yeah. And that was, like, right after the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting. Just awful timing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report came just days after a man believed to have held such views shot 11 dead at a Pittsburgh synagogue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then Vice managed to set up fake ads that looked like they were from Senators, with barely any effort. Facebook just approved them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Vice managed to set up fake ads that looked like they were from Senators, with barely any effort. Facebook just approved them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vice was able to set up ads purportedly backed by Senators. The reporter had to do little more than lie about who he worked for and who he was, and Facebook approved the ads.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And Business Insider even got ads approved claiming to be paid for by Cambridge Analytica, which, you know, given their history...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And Business Insider even got ads approved claiming to be paid for by Cambridge Analytica, which, you know, given their history...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And Business Insider reported Facebook approved its ads that claimed to have been paid for by Cambridge Analytica, the data analytics company that was at the center of a furore around access to personal information belonging to users of the social media website.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! So much for that "Paid for by" feature they introduced for transparency. It seems like it's causing more confusion than clarity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! So much for that Paid for by feature they introduced for transparency. It seems like it's causing more confusion than clarity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In May, Facebook announced the Paid for by feature, which was supposed to bring transparency about who was behind the ads. It appears that thanks to the obvious ease with which it can be manipulated, it may be causing more confusion than clarity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's easily manipulated, isn't it? So, what's the DPC in Ireland going to do with all this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's easily manipulated, isn't it? So, what's the D P C in Ireland going to do with all this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the Irish regulator hasn't actually *received* the referral yet. But once they do, they're going to assess it and decide if any punishment is required.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the Irish regulator hasn't actually received the referral yet. But once they do, they're going to assess it and decide if any punishment is required.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Irish regulator has not yet received the referral, however. As and when it's forthcoming, the body will explore Facebook's practises and and whether any punishment is required. Once this referral has been received by the DPC, we will assess the information and decide then what steps are required.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They're saying they regularly engage with regulators, believe their tools comply with EU data protection laws, and they're looking forward to, uh, continuing discussions with the DPC.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're saying they regularly engage with regulators, believe their tools comply with E U data protection laws, and they're looking forward to, uh, continuing discussions with the D P C.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A Facebook spokesperson said: We regularly engage with regulators regarding our advertising tools, which we believe fully comply with EU data protection laws. We look forward to continuing these discussions with the Irish Data Protection Commissioner, as our lead regulator on data protection matters under the GDPR.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Sounds like they've got their work cut out for them, yet again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sounds like they've got their work cut out for them, yet again.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Another day, another data privacy kerfuffle for Facebook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Another day, another data privacy kerfuffle for Facebook.
